  physical_appearance: This is a skirt with pleated sides. The skirt has a brown waistband. It is made of pink patterned cloth. In the middle
 there is a panel bordered by blue floral embroidery. In the center
 there are two medallions bordered by a gold thread. In the medallions
 there is a depiction of a woman with a child in her arms
 and a man in official robes in a garden.

  subject_terms_1: flower (motif) foliage (motif) embroidery (visual works) folk costume

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Skirts Ethnic costume Embroidery

  subject_terms_3: Chinese costumes

  sgcool_label_text: The skirt was worn with a loosely-fitted jacket. Taken together
 the two-piece ensemble was known as aoqun
 a popular form of Han Chinese dress during the Qing dynasty. The sides of the skirt are finely pleated.  Set against a gold thread background
 two medallions depict a woman holding a child in her arms and a man in official robes strolling in a garden. Skirts with pleated sides became very popular during the Qing dynasty. The fact that some skirts had as many as 100 pleats earned this type of garment the name ‘fish-scale skirt of 100 pleats’.

metadata.title_text: Pink Chinese skirt Pink Han Chinese skirt
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a skirt with pleated sides. The skirt has a brown waistband. It is made of pink patterned cloth. In the middle, there is a panel bordered by blue floral embroidery. In the center, there are two medallions bordered by a gold thread. In the medallions, there is a depiction of a woman with a child in her arms, and a man in official robes in a garden.
metadata.subject_terms_1: flower (motif) foliage (motif) embroidery (visual works) folk costume
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The skirt was worn with a loosely-fitted jacket. Taken together, the two-piece ensemble was known as aoqun, a popular form of Han Chinese dress during the Qing dynasty. The sides of the skirt are finely pleated.  Set against a gold thread background, two medallions depict a woman holding a child in her arms and a man in official robes strolling in a garden. Skirts with pleated sides became very popular during the Qing dynasty. The fact that some skirts had as many as 100 pleats earned this type of garment the name ‘fish-scale skirt of 100 pleats’.
